awd_abstract_narration: Physicists from the University of Rochester will continue                  their research on the study of heavy quarks and related topics.                 They will use two electron-positron colliding beam facilities,                  one in the U.S. at Cornell University and the second in Japan at                KEK (National High Energy Physics Laboratory).                                       1.  At KEK, they will design and construct an instrument to                be used to identify electrons to be used with a major particle                  detector (called AMI) at the newly commissioned Tristan storage                 ring facility.                                                                       2.  At the Cornell Electron Storage Ring, they will work                   with the particle detector (known as CLEO II) now being upgraded.               They will study the weak decays of b-quarks to measure some of                  the fundamental parameters of the electro-weak interactions.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences
